title: Paul's Ministry in Ephesus
shortSummary: Acts 19 details Paul's extended ministry in Ephesus, highlighting the reception of the Holy Spirit by new believers, miraculous healings, and the powerful spread of the gospel. The chapter also describes a significant opposition from local craftsmen whose livelihood depended on idol worship, culminating in a public uproar. This narrative underscores the transformative power of the gospel and the inevitable conflict it brings in a pagan society.
timeline: c. AD 53-55 - Paul's Third Missionary Journey in Ephesus

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle and missionary who ministers boldly in Ephesus, performing miracles and teaching about Jesus Christ.

keyCharacters.name: Demetrius
keyCharacters.description: A silversmith in Ephesus who leads a protest against Paul because his trade of making shrines to Diana is threatened.

keyCharacters.name: Sons of Sceva
keyCharacters.description: Seven Jewish exorcists who unsuccessfully attempt to cast out evil spirits in Jesus' name, demonstrating the power of true faith.

keyCharacters.name: Timotheus and Erastus
keyCharacters.description: Assistants sent by Paul into Macedonia while Paul remains in Asia for a time.

definitions.definition: The third Person of the Trinity, also known as the Holy Spirit, who empowers believers and convicts the world of sin.
A baptism of repentance preached by John the Baptist, preparing people to receive Christ but not the full Christian baptism.
Occult practices or magical arts, often associated with sorcery or witchcraft, which new believers renounced and destroyed.
The Roman goddess of the hunt, worshiped in Ephesus; her temple was a major religious and economic center.
Individuals who claim to cast out evil spirits, often invoking spiritual authority, but without true faith in Christ.

outline.heading: Paul's Encounter with Disciples and Baptism in Jesus' Name
outline.description: Paul finds disciples in Ephesus who had only received John's baptism and instructs them about Jesus and the Holy Spirit, leading to their baptism in Jesus' name and receiving the Holy Spirit with miraculous signs.

outline.heading: Paul's Teaching and Miracles in Ephesus
outline.description: Paul boldly teaches in the synagogue and the school of Tyrannus for two years, during which God performs extraordinary miracles through him, confirming the gospel's power.

outline.heading: The Sons of Sceva and the Power of Jesus' Name
outline.description: Seven Jewish exorcists attempt to use Jesus' name without faith and are overcome by an evil spirit, demonstrating that spiritual authority belongs to true believers.

outline.heading: Repentance and Renunciation of Sorcery
outline.description: Many new believers confess their sins and burn their books of magic, showing genuine repentance and the transformative effect of the gospel in Ephesus.

outline.heading: Paul's Plans and the Riot in Ephesus
outline.description: Paul plans to travel to Jerusalem and Rome; meanwhile, Demetrius incites a riot to protect the idol-making trade, leading to a city-wide disturbance that is eventually quelled by the town clerk.

application: Seek the fullness of the Holy Spirit after believing in Christ, as Paul taught the disciples in Ephesus.
Boldly proclaim and defend the gospel even when faced with opposition or misunderstanding.
Confess and renounce sinful practices, allowing the gospel to transform every area of life.
Trust in the authority of Jesus' name and be cautious of counterfeit spiritual practices.

keyVerses.text: And when Paul had laid his hands upon them, the Holy Ghost came on them; and they spake with tongues, and prophesied.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the reception of the Holy Spirit as a powerful confirmation of faith and the presence of God's power in the early church.

keyVerses.text: So mightily grew the word of God and prevailed.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the unstoppable growth and influence of the gospel despite opposition.

keyVerses.text: So that not only this our craft is in danger to be set at nought; but also that the temple of the great goddess Diana should be despised, and her magnificence should be destroyed, whom all Asia and the world worshippeth.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the economic and religious conflict caused by the gospelâ€™s challenge to idolatry.

keyVerses.text: And when the townclerk had appeased the people, he said, Ye men of Ephesus, what man is there that knoweth not how that the city of the Ephesians is a worshipper of the great goddess Diana, and of the image which fell down from Jupiter?
keyVerses.significance: It shows the attempt to restore order and reason amid chaos, acknowledging the cultural context of Ephesus.
